search.slidetext: easement stewardship basics module 2:introduction to management
central stewardship activity working with land owners to achieve conservation outcomes. management: planning for outcomes maintenance enhancement landowner authorizations

learning objectives after completing this module, you will be able to: describe the function, required components, and key characteristics of an easement plan. define “management” and “maintenance,” explaining how they differ. specify the purpose and requirements of a management plan and an operation and maintenance (o&m) plan. summarize nrcs and landowner roles and responsibilities for the management and maintenance of stewardship lands. define and summarize the purpose of landowner authorizations. describe when and how to grant a compatible use authorization (cua). explain the landowner’s obligations under the compatible use authorization (cua) and how to ensure the best outcomes.

definitions term definition conservation activity activity performed that contributes to the protection, preservation, management, or restoration of natural resources on agricultural, pasture, forest, and other associated lands. conservation practice a structural or vegetative measure, or management activity used to protect or reduce the degradation of soil, water, air, plant, animal, or energy resources. conservation practices are standardized to ensure quality, consistency, and environmental compliance.
lesson 1: easement plans lesson 1 learning objective: describe the function, required components, and key characteristics of an easement plan.
our vibrant world steadfast rhythms constant flux the dynamic nature of our world demands active management to fulfill the obligations of easement stewardship.

management objectives examples of management objectives: biological diversity habitat structure and function special features for wildlife control or reduce invasive species easement management ensures that program objectives are accomplished using conservation activities and practices over the course of time.

easement plans examples of easement plans wetlands reserve plan of operations (wrpo) operation & maintenance (o&m) plan (how to use and take care) forest management plan the main vehicle driving the management function are the various easement plans associated with each site.

easement plans: required components required components clearly identified objective plan map showing: easement boundary applied conservation practices location of planned restoration practices, habitats, and planned land use planned conservation practices job sheets (detailed descriptions of planned practices) practice specifications

easement plan: key characteristics 1. developed by nrcs staff with appropriate training and authority forester biologist grassland specialist soil scientist archeologist environmental/wetland engineer key characteristics of an easement plan: 2. living document version 1 version 2 version 3

knowledge check 1 which of the following statements are true among easement plans? select all that apply.
next up: management vs. maintenance management vs. maintenance

lesson 2: management vs. maintenance lesson 2 learning objectives: define management and maintenance, explaining how they differ. specify the purpose and requirements of a management plan and an operation and maintenance (o&m) plan.
maintenance falls under management working with land owners to achieve conservation outcomes. management: planning for outcomes maintenance enhancement landowner authorizations

management plans management plans prescribe how lands will be managed how restoration practices will be implemented guardrails to meet the program objective management plans set the vision for achievingintended outcomes.

management plan components management plans should: summarize goals, objectives, and outcomes identify strategies and management practices list activities and management practices outline contingency plans for unexpected changesor conditions describe how monitoring results will be used management plans are fundamentally shaped by the easement program, site conditions, and the best available science.

operation and maintenance operation daily tasks and functions practice in compliance serve purpose for which the practice was installed maintenance keep easement functioning for program purposes prevent degradation repair damage replace practice components that fail

examples of maintenance maintenance of structures maintenance of habitat cracking, sloughing of leaks in dikes and levees faulty pumps and power units clogged water control structures and pipelines erosion planting failures poor vegetation establishment presence of noxious or invasive weeds
funding for maintenance the nrcs easement programs division annually allocates program funding towards easement stewardship activities, including maintenance, at the state level.

operation and maintenance (o&m) plans required for most installed practices stewardship lands generally limited to structural practices operation and maintenance plans identify activities needed to maintain and restore a practice in a functioning condition.

operation and maintenance (o&m) plan components plan components detailed identification of maintenance activities list of specific items to inspect remedial actions for problems review with the landowner fully understand operation and maintenance (o&m) needs

your takeaway management: vision and planning to meet long-term goals maintenance: daily operations to keep easement functioning and progressing toward stated goals. management includes maintenance
next up: management roles and responsibilities management roles and responsibilities
lesson 3: management roles and responsibilities lesson 3 learning objective: summarize nrcs and landowner roles and responsibilities for management and maintenance of stewardship lands.
a management partnership management and maintenance is a partnership between nrcs and the landowners.

nrcs responsibilities nrcs will: determine if repair, management, maintenance or replacement of any practice is warranted. if necessary, utilize landowner or 3rd party contractor to implement the practices and activities. provide landowner or 3rd party adequate details for successful performance.

nrcs boundary management nrcs is responsible for managing easement boundaries: identifying location of boundary marking boundary with signs reestablishment survey necessary when nrcs determines property boundary needs to be redefined questions and requests easementsupport@usda.gov
landowner responsibilities maintenance activities in accordance with the final plan of operations maintenance of structural practices

noxious weed control noxious weed control landowner responsible per easement deed and applicable federal, state, and local laws nrcs-approved compatible use authorization (cua) required prior to implementation a noxious weed is any plant designated by federal, state or local government officials as detrimental to public health, agriculture, wildlife or property.

nrcs final authority nrcs policy nrcs’ intent is to allow landowners the opportunity to participate in the restoration and management process. in the event of disagreement, nrcs will always try to collaborate with the landowner in good faith. nrcs is the final decision maker and has authority to restore and manage easements as nrcs determines best.

no enforcement authority landowner engagement and agreement is always the preferable outcome. nrcs can’t force management or maintenance. avoid management plans that rely too heavily on the landowner be prepared to fully manage the easement

next up: landowner authorizations landowner authorizations
lesson 4: landowner authorizations lesson 4 learning objective: define and summarize the purpose of landowner authorizations.

introduction to landowner authorizations landowner authorization authorization to conduct stewardship activities that are: consistent with the long-term protection and enhancement of the easement not otherwise prohibited by the deed part of an easement plan (hfrp and grp) by purchasing an easement, nrcs acquires all land management rights and responsibilities for that land.

landowner authorization illustration it’s up to nrcs whether to grant the request. once authorized, the landowner must abide by the rules to retain the authorization. verbiage taken from usda compatible use authorization form ad-1160: “nrcs retains the right to modify or cancel this compatible use authorization at any time if the nrcs determines that such activities do not further the protection and enhancement objectives of the easement, or that the landowner has failed to comply with specified terms and conditions.” “the landowner engages in such activities at his/her own risk.” “this authorization does not vest any right of any kind in the landowner.” “this authorization is null and void after the expiration date specified above.“ “by signing this document, the landowner agrees to the terms described above and on referenced documents.“ think of the landowner authorization like a permit.

easement deeds reserved rights part ii. reservations in the landowner on the easement area. subject to the rights, title, and interest conveyed by this easement deed to the united states, including the restoration, protection, management, maintenance, enhancement, and monitoring of the wetland and other natural values of the easement area, the landowner reserves: prohibited activities part iii. obligations of the landowner. the landowner shall comply with all terms and conditions of this easement, including the following: a. prohibitions. without otherwise limiting the rights of the united states acquired hereunder, it is expressly understood that the rights to carry out the following activities and uses have been acquired by the united states and, unless authorized by the united states under part iv, are prohibited on the easement area: different easement programs have different deeds with different reserved rights and prohibited activities. example verbiage taken from the agricultural conservation easement program – wetland reserve easement (acep-wre) warranty easement deed:

reserved rights reserved grazing rights undeveloped recreational uses control of access examples* of reserved rights for landowners: *always refer to the deed for the rights and prohibitions applicable to a specific easement.

prohibited activities building structures dumping mowing examples* of prohibited activities for landowners: *always refer to the deed for the rights and prohibitions applicable to a specific easement.

forms of authorization all landowner easement activities must fall into one of the following categories: reserved rights as set forth in the warranty easement deed authorized by a plan update authorized by a compatible use authorization (cua) note: landowner authorizations are only available under stewardship, or us-held easements. *refer to the easement deed to verify that a compatible use authorization is permitted. program plan update cua acep-wre x ewpp-fpe x ewrp x wrp x rcpp-us held* x rcpp-wre x grp x hfrp x rcpp-hfrp x landowner authorization documents

next up: compatible use authorizations compatible use authorizations

lesson 5: compatible use authorizations lesson 5 learning objectives: describe when and how to grant a compatible use authorization (cua). explain the landowner’s obligations under the cua and how to ensure the best outcomes.
when to grant cuas compatible use authorizations (cuas) required for approved activities management or maintenance implemented by the landowner or agent prescribed burning

cua conditions “not harming” or “no impact” is not good enough reason for authorization authorized compatible use authorizations must: further the long-term protection and enhancement of easement values benefit the purposes of the easement not adversely affect wildlife habitat over the long term
commonly authorized activities vegetation management: prescribed burning semi-permanent hunting and observation blinds wildlife food plots mowed trails shallow water management

cua example considerations: mowing on water control structures does the activity benefit the functions and values of the easement? how is a secondary practice like herbicide needed to help control the type of woody vegetation beyond just mowing? what type of equipment can be safely used on that type of water control structure? when is the timing correct to avoid wildlife impacts such as primary bird nesting season? where is a trail needed to get the mowing equipment to and from the site?

compatible use authorization process compatible use authorization requests landowner requests compatible use authorization in writing or verbally or nrcs initiates contact with the landowner to recommend a request only the landowner of record can be issued a compatible use authorization.

conservation desktop final packet must be user friendly the landowner must clearly understand where, how, and when to implement management and maintenance practices. compatible use authorizations are managed through conservation desktop (cd) using form ad-1160.

cua form required information b. purpose: the purpose should clearly state how the activity will further long-term quality habitat and for what species, including predefined practices with corresponding expiration dates. c. location: defining location ensures that the activity takes place on the planned acreage and does not stray on to adjacent or noncontiguous acres where the activity may do irreparable damage to existing habitat. d. beginning condition of site: this section provides a brief description of current habitat conditions of the area where the practice will be implemented. e. statement of affect and compatibility: this section describes the beneficial impacts of implementing the practice within the easement area. f. special conditions, specifications and other details: this section outlines specific details such as frequency, timing, intensity, extent, duration of the practice, and specific restrictions, if any, as well as additional information from consultation with partner conservation agencies. select the image thumbnail within each marker panel to zoom in.

landowner activity under cuas if landowner chooses to start implementation: abide by compatible use authorization terms and conditions follow associated plans if landowner abandons activities that disturbs vegetative cover: reestablish native vegetation at own expense if deemed necessary by nrcs landowners are not obligated to implement the activities in an authorized cua. abandoned food plot

communicate early and often the landowner authorization is a vital part of the communication flow. from the earliest point possible, make sure landowner understands: easement program their reserved rights prohibitions restoration management maintenance how authorized activities and management are tiered to the deed

wrap up: stay true to the why wrap up: easement stewardship management is anchored in the “why” while allowing for flexibility in the “how.”

" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="To view a list of keyboard shortcuts, press Shift + ?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="To view the transcript, select the menu icon in the upper left and navigate to the Transcription tab." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="As shown in our three-pronged Stewardship model, Management is central to NRCS’ stewardship responsibilities. Management encompasses the planning, maintenance, and enhancement of easements in partnership with landowners to achieve target outcomes." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Before we get started, there are a few key terms you should get to know. Please review the definitions on-screen for a better understanding of the learning ahead." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="For eons, our natural world has been characterized by rhythms as steadfast as the ebb and flow of the tides. At the same time, these systems are constantly in flux, which is often escalated due to natural disasters, invasive species, and human intervention. The dynamic nature of our world demands active management to fulfill the obligations of easement stewardship." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Easement management ensures that program objectives are accomplished using conservation activities and practices over the course of time.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Depending on the program, examples of management objectives might include:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="72" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="36" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Biological diversity
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="72" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="36" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Reinforcement of habitat structure and function
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="72" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="36" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Enhancement of special features for wildlife, and 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="72" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="36" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Control or reduction of invasive species." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The main vehicle driving the management function are the various easement plans associated with each site. “Easement Plan” is a general term that describes a host of possible types of plans that may be associated with an easement, such as the Wetlands Reserve Plan of Operations (WRPO), Operation & Maintenance (O&M) Plan, or a Forest Management Plan. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Regardless of the plan type, easement plans must include the required components displayed on-screen. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="All easement plans share two key characteristics.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="First of all, these plans are developed by NRCS staff, with appropriate training and authority to plan objectives based on science and professional expertise.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Second of all, easement plans are living documents that anticipate continual modifications. This is necessary since ecosystems are not static and change, sometimes dramatically, over time. That means very few, if any, plans should ever be identified as “final.”" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Shown on-screen is a broader list of situations that may require an update to management strategies. Please note that this list is not exhaustive, and we should lean towards updating plans more often than not. Deciding when a plan needs updating gets easier with time!" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Reflect upon what you’ve learned so far about stewardship management and answer the question shown here. Select all that apply. Once you have made your selection, select Submit." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="In the next lesson, we will consider the difference between easement management and maintenance, as well as easement plans pertaining to each." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Maintenance represents a significant portion of easement stewardship activities but falls under the umbrella of Management. Let’s take a look at two types of easement plans to put management and maintenance into proper context. We will start with management plans." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Every stewarded easement should have a management plan. Management plans are the best way to set a vision for the outcomes NRCS intends for the site, prescribe how lands will be managed, and how restoration practices will be implemented to maximize functions and values. In an ever-changing environment, management plans are the best way to ensure the land will progress toward the program objective." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="While plan specifics will vary from site to site, management plans are fundamentally shaped by the easement program, site conditions, and the best available science. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Management plans should accomplish the following: 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="36" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Summarize project goals, objectives, and outcomes.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="36" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Identify strategies and specific management practices to achieve project goals and objectives.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="36" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	List the schedule of activities and management practices.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="36" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Outline contingency plans for unexpected changes or conditions.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="36" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Describe how monitoring results will be used to modify or direct management strategies." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="After the initial restoration, NRCS must continue to steward the site to ensure the programmatic and site-specific objectives are met and the easement maximizes the benefits for which it was acquired. This is where operation and maintenance come in.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="“Operation” refers to the daily tasks and functions associated with easement operations—in compliance with all laws, regulations, and ordinances—to serve the purpose for which it was installed.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="“Maintenance” is defined as work performed to keep the easement functioning for program purposes. Maintenance activity includes preventing deterioration, repairing damage, or replacing practice components that fail." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Two common examples of maintenance activities include maintenance of structures and maintenance of habitat. Both require routine inspection and upkeep to ensure installed practices achieve their purposes and meet their intended operational lifespan. Select each picture to view a few things to look for during inspection." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="It should be noted that the NRCS allocates a significant percentage of program funding toward easement stewardship activities, including maintenance, at the state level." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="An Operation and Maintenance Plan is a written document identifying activities needed to maintain and restore a practice in a functioning condition.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="“O&Ms,” as they are known, are required for most practices installed on NRCS stewardship lands. Operation and maintenance activities are generally limited to structural practices on the easement." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The operation and maintenance plan has several required plan components.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The operation and maintenance plan should include enough detail to identify all maintenance activities that are likely to be needed and should specify how and when to accomplish them. Additionally, the plan should include a list of specific items to inspect and remedial actions to be taken when problems are discovered.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The plan should be prepared by NRCS and reviewed with the landowner to ensure a full understanding of the operation and maintenance needs." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="Which of the following would fall under management, but not maintenance? Select all that apply. Once you have made your selection, select Submit." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="True or False: The operation and maintenance plan contains a lot of detail internally relevant to NRCS and should not be shared with the landowner. Once you have made your selection, select Submit." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="To summarize, management ensures the original vision for easement restoration is pursued. It is characterized by long-term planning for how to achieve specific program objectives and outcomes on a conservation easement.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Management includes maintenance. Maintenance focuses on day-to-day operations to keep the easement functioning and progressing towards stated goals." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="In the next lesson, we will learn how management roles and responsibilities are distributed between the parties." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Easement stewardship is a partnership between NRCS and the landowners. This partnership extends to maintenance and management responsibilities." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="NRCS will determine if repair, management, maintenance, or replacement of any practice is warranted. The activities are then documented in the Operation and Maintenance plan.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="While NRCS is responsible, our easement programs were designed to empower landowners to take on management work. NRCS can authorize landowners or third-party contractors to carry out conservation activities through an appropriate contracting vehicle. We will go into greater detail on landowner authorizations in the next lesson.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="To ensure that conservation activities are clearly understood and successfully performed, NRCS will provide adequate details of the practices in writing." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="NRCS has the notable responsibility of managing easement boundaries. Part of that responsibility is knowing exactly where our easement boundaries fall on the landscape. We must ensure these boundaries are accurately marked with signs and replace any that are missing. In cases of boundary discrepancies, disputes, or uncertainty, it may be necessary to complete a reestablishment survey. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Boundary reestablishment is a complex issue. Direct any questions and survey requests to the Easement Programs Division (EPD)." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="We now move on to the landowner. The landowner should be actively engaged and is responsible for the maintenance of the easement in accordance with the management plan. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="This means that landowners should maintain all structural components in good operating condition. Additional types of maintenance work commonly taken on by landowners include tree removal from water control structures, brush management, and mowing grasses planted for firebreaks." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="A noxious weed is any plant designated by Federal, State, or local government officials as detrimental to public health, agriculture, wildlife or property. Landowners are legally responsible for noxious weed control per the easement deed and applicable Federal, State, and local laws.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Although the landowner is required to control noxious weeds by the easement terms and various laws, the landowner must obtain an approved compatible use authorization, or CUA, prior to implementation of any maintenance activities by the landowner. We will cover compatible use authorizations in more depth in a later lesson.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Single" LineSpacing="20" SpacingBefore="5" SpacingAfter="5"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The compatible use authorization allows NRCS to ensure the weed control activity doesn't interfere with restoration plans, follows best management practices, and will be effective for the targeted weed species. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="According to NRCS policy, NRCS’ intent is to allow landowners the opportunity to participate in the restoration and management process. In the event of disagreement, NRCS will always try to collaborate with the landowner in good faith.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="However, NRCS is the final decision maker and has authority to restore and manage easements as NRCS determines best. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="As you’ve seen in this lesson, landowners are sometimes granted additional responsibilities on the easement through landowner authorizations. This is our topic for the next lesson." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="By purchasing an easement, NRCS acquires all land management rights and responsibilities for that land.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Landowners may request a landowner authorization from NRCS to conduct stewardship activities that are consistent with the long-term protection and enhancement of the easement and not otherwise prohibited by the deed.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="For the HFRP and GRP programs, NRCS may also grant landowner authorizations by updating the management plan." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="You might think of a landowner authorization like a kind of permit to undertake a particular management activity. It’s up to NRCS whether to grant the request or not. Once authorized, the landowner must abide by all of the rules to retain the authorization." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="To understand the rationale for landowner authorizations, we must go back to the easement deed. Different easement programs have different deeds with different reserved rights and prohibited activities." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Easement deeds spell out every right the landowner retains on an easement. Some reserved rights include the right to control access, the right to undeveloped recreational uses, and reserved grazing rights." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The deed also sets forth a list of activities and uses that are prohibited on the easement, such as mowing, dumping, or placing structures within the easement area.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Along with prohibitions, the easement deed provides examples of types of activities that MAY be authorized by NRCS through a landowner authorization when NRCS deems them appropriate. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="All landowner easement activities must fall into one of the following categories:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="72" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="36" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Reserved rights as set forth in the Warranty Easement Deed
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="72" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="36" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Authorized by a plan update 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="72" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="36" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="·	Authorized by a compatible use authorization
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="36" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="0" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="In other words, when not specifically listed as a reserved right in the deed, activities may be authorized either through management plan updates or compatible use authorizations, depending on the easement program. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Note that Landowner Authorizations are only available under stewardship, or US-held easements." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="As we just learned, landowner authorization is documented by way of a compatible use authorization, or CUA, for most easement programs. In our next lesson, we will consider the compatible use authorization in greater detail." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="A compatible use authorization is required for any approved management or maintenance activity within or outside the easement area. The activities may be implemented by either the landowner or their agent." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="A compatible use authorization may only be issued when the proposed use is consistent with the long-term protection and enhancement of easement values, clearly benefits the purposes for which the easement was acquired, and does not adversely affect habitat for migratory bird, at risk species, or threatened and endangered species. ​
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Not harming or having no impact to the easement’s functions and values alone is not good enough reason to authorize a compatible use authorization." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Commonly granted compatible use authorizations include shallow water management, mowing trails, establishing wildlife food plots, installing semi-permanent hunting and observation blinds, and a spectrum of vegetation management activities. Each of these activities comes with its own standards and specifications which tell the landowner how, where, and when to conduct the activity. " /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Compatible use authorizations are now developed and managed through Conservation Desktop. The final packet, which includes a completed compatible use authorization form and supporting documents, must be user friendly so that the landowner can clearly understand where, how, and when to implement management and maintenance practices." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Select or click each marker for a brief description of the main inputs you will be required to provide on the compatible use authorization form. Select the image thumbnail within each marker panel to zoom in." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="For the best possible outcomes, the importance of clear, frequent communication with landowners cannot be overstated. From the earliest point possible, make sure the landowner understands the program, their reserved rights and prohibitions, restoration, management, maintenance, and how management is tiered from the easement deed.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" ListLevel="1" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The landowner authorization is a vital part of the communication flow. Well-written landowner authorizations clarify management methods and details, which serves to educate landowners and prevent violations." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style /> <Span Text="True or False: Landowners are required to fully carry out the activities authorized by a compatible use authorization. Once you have made your selection, select Submit." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" Color="#000000" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="We’ve covered a broad range of topics in this course related to the planning involved and the distribution of responsibilities in the management of easement lands, yet we’ve only scratched the surface.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="The truth is that we all learn as we go—from the landowners, from our colleagues, and from the land itself. Our collective knowledge leads us to more effective and impactful stewardship for a healthier world." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style FlowDirection="LeftToRight" LeadingMargin="0" TrailingMargin="0" FirstLineMargin="0" Justification="Left" LineSpacingRule="Multiple" LineSpacing="21" SpacingBefore="0" SpacingAfter="8"> <ListStyle ListType="None" ListTypeFormat="Parentheses" BulletFont="Arial" /> </Style> <Span Text="Congratulations! You have now completed the course on Management. The following modules will focus on the remaining two buckets of easement stewardship activities: Monitoring and Compliance. Thank you for your commitment to this journey." /> </Block> </Content> </Document>
